animalOfTheDay.name: sable
facts: Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.
They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.

calendar.name: raven
facts: In mythology, they are often symbols of wisdom or trickery.
They can mimic human speech and other sounds, though not as well as parrots.
Ravens are among the smartest birds, capable of problem-solving and tool use.
Ravens play games, such as sliding down snowbanks or dropping sticks in flight to catch them.

calendar.name: red panda
facts: Red pandas are solitary and mark territory with scent glands on their feet.
They have a false thumb, an extended wrist bone, to help grip bamboo.
Red pandas are not closely related to giant pandas but share a bamboo-heavy diet.
They are endangered, with fewer than 10,000 left in the wild due to habitat loss.

calendar.name: rhinoceros
facts: They communicate through grunts, snorts, and even infrasound below human hearing.
Rhinos have thick skin, but it can be sensitive to sunburn and insect bites, leading them to wallow in mud.
All five rhino species are threatened by poaching, with three critically endangered.
Rhino horns are made of keratin, the same protein as human hair and nails.

calendar.name: robin
facts: Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'
They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.

calendar.name: rook
facts: Rooks have pale, featherless faces that distinguish them from other crows.
Rooks are highly social corvids that nest in large colonies called rookeries.
They are among the most intelligent birds and can use simple tools.
They form lifelong pair bonds and often stay with the same mate for life.

calendar.name: rottweiler
facts: Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.
Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.
They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.

calendar.name: sable
facts: They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.
Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.

randomAnimals.name: albatross
facts: They have the largest wingspan of any living bird, reaching up to 12 feet.
Albatrosses can fly for hours without flapping their wings, using dynamic soaring.
They can sleep while flying by shutting down half their brain at a time.
These birds can live over 60 years and mate for life.

randomAnimals.name: blue-footed booby
facts: Their nostrils are permanently closed, and they breathe through the corners of their beak, which prevents water from entering during dives.
Blue-footed boobies are seabirds from the Pacific, known for their bright blue feet, which play a role in courtship.
They are excellent divers, plunging from heights of up to 24 meters (80 feet) to catch fish.
Males perform an elaborate courtship dance, displaying their blue feet to attract females.

randomAnimals.name: basset hound
facts: Their short legs and long body make them excellent at following trails slowly.
They were originally bred in France for hunting small game.
Basset hounds have the second-best sense of smell among all dog breeds.
Their long ears help sweep scents from the ground toward their nose.
